author: drummerboye
body: Rent for a one bedroom apartment is like $2,000 but rent for a 4-br house is $3,000. It pays to get married and live with the wife and her boyfriend.

author: Competitive_Ad498
body:
So Do you hold a bearish position at this point? Sitting on the sidelines? Invested like everyone else anyway while being scared? 
Like what’s your actual position?

You realize the entire design of the stock market is for it to go up over time right? With no assets classes other than blockchain tech derivatives that can compete from an alpha standpoint it means that all savings from people’s earnings get pumped into the stock market. Most of the investing money in the world is managed by about 30 people at black rock and vanguard. The money that isn’t managed by them has to follow and trade based around the way br and vanguard trade or get run over. 
Until there’s a fundamental change in how the institutions manage the system, going against their grain will just make you cry. 
Yes there will be small dips and sector rotations and some stocks will be riskier than others. But the market overall will continue up over time and stay within a sensible pe range like it always has.

author: DavidW19999
body:
Bit Defender has a really good one with a pretty reasonable annual fee, and no degraded throughout that I can detect. Avoid bypasses / work arounds like your finances depend on it, bcuz they do.  Same thing I tell my kinders, ‘Free is NEVER free in the end. You won’t know you’ve slammed until they’ve already left.’  

Free Perspective: the machine I conduct financial transactions with is on an independent network and separate ISP set to high security over a dedicated cat-6 cable I ran.  (No, I will NOT use WiFi for fin transactions from primary accounts, Too easily intercepted. This was done AFTER my little Cherubs took out my machine, wife’s laptop, printer, and half the smoke detectors when they DL’d a free vpn program containing a worm that propagated through the home network. Started getting ‘dark-net’ traffic warnings to change all account passwords next day. (Convo with the kid: Duuuuh, you didn’t think anything when you downloaded from the .ru  and .br domains??????) Not Computer or Network Management Advice, only what I’d do. ;-)

author: Vagabond_Crambus
body: Shit, even people with little 2 BR condos near me in central NJ can pay well over $10k in property tax.

author: Waycock
body:
I agree - even if you have a 20% downpayment on a 1 br in Waterloo say. A newer 1 br condo unit is around $450,000. So total mortgage amount is $400,000. Monkey around with the income numbers here on the qualifier and remember, the average income in 2019 was $49,000 ($37,800 is median...) - https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/tv.action?pid=1110023901

The numbers are so off - something will break. Either society or the market.

author: badtradesguy
body: take calculated risks based on your portfolios expected growth and annual income that can br saved. If you are too risk averse you wont have good returns.

author: Honeycombhome
body: It is. I live in Montrose where I’m within walking distance of a lot of cafes, a really nice grocery store, and a few parks and art galleries. The only downside is my one bedroom is kind of small at 750sf. If you’re wondering why my rent is so cheap it’s bc I split an $800 1 br with my SO. Utilities and internet is about another $100/mo so $50 each.

author: Difficult_Delay_8604
body:
If you want to learn about technical analysis

* Learn about trend indicators e.g. moving averages, momentum indicators e.g. Oscillators, volatility indicators e.g. Bollinger Bands, Volume indicators e.g. Chaikin Money Flow
* Support and resistance lines
* Read some books about technical analysis. This one is a good overview but it focuses more on futures but the stuff is generally applicable to stocks as well: "Technical Analysis of the Financial Markets: A Comprehensive Guide to Trading Methods and Applications". Use z-lib or some other book pirating sites
* Try and stay away from price action because that's the most suspect of all technical analysis. On the other hand, algorithmic/system trading is arguably the most rigorous of technical analysis based strategies.

If you want to learn about fundamental analysis

* Learn about multipliers and other fundamentals e.g. P/E, EBITA, EV.
* Learn how to make financial models e.g. Here's Martin Shkreli teaching how to build a financial model with IBM as an example [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fASInVKShnM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fASInVKShnM) (disclaimer, I think this particular valuation turned out to be wrong so focus more on the techniques/models used rather than specifics about the companies) and here's DeepFuckingValue valuing GME [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GZTr1-Gp74U](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GZTr1-Gp74U). I think they make this type of dry stuff more "accessible" for the average person?
* Read some books. I've heard intelligent investor by Benjamin Graham is good, although I haven't read it so see what the others here think

But honestly, just buy ETFs and save enough to retire.

author: Afrofreak1
body:
We are talking multiple years here if not decades. Companies like Exxon. a.) They are in a dying industry and have been unsuccessful in pivoting away from fossil fuels to alternative sources of revenue. b.) They are a poorly run company that has had multiple CEOs in the past 10 years. c.) They have had declining revenue since 2014. d.) They are not reinvesting a lot of their profits back into the business because so much of it is released to shareholders as dividends. They know that that is one of the few reasons they are still in a lot of portfolios and ETFs. "tHey pAy a HeAlThY dIvIdEnD." Yes, but as a result they are backed into a corner and their business plan is basically: Extract as much value from the business as possible while we still can. 

Does that mean that you can't make money off Exxon stock? No, ofc not, and in fact it's one of the best performing stocks in the S&P500 this year. However, a company that has peaked without any contingency plan to continued growth will never be able to match the returns of a company like Microsoft or Google that are growing 20+% Y-o-Y top and bottom line. I will happily pay a premium to companies that have an outstanding track record and ample room to grow and, more importantly, *the proven ability to seek out alternative sources of revenue*. That is not priced in because we don't even know where these companies are headed until they tell us. I am putting my faith in Nadella and Pichai to lead those companies to growth opportunities that investors hadn't even considered yet. 

Meanwhile back at Exxon they are just doing damage control to make sure that their dividend is paid at all costs. That is a terrible investment strategy and the difference in returns over the past decade show it. How likely is it do you think that Exxon will continue down this path and likewise for Microsoft and Google? I do not want companies that don't have a bright future ahead because the potential for sizeable returns is just so much smaller. Unfortunately, companies like Exxon still occupy a sizeable chunk in the S&P500 because once-upon-a-time Exxon in particular was the largest company in the world by market cap. As a result, it drops the S&P500s total return hence why I went with the NASDAQ-100. 

It's not that I'm actively *picking* tech stocks, it's that I'm *removing* chronically underperforming companies like Exxon, Chevron, Wells Fargo, IBM, Ford, GM, etc. and the NASDAQ is the most similar to what an ideal portfolio would look like.
